message_1: A student needs to choose a team of 3 students from a group of 5 students. How many different teams can be formed? (Hint: Use the binomial coefficient formula, also known as "n choose k", where n is the total number of students and k is the number of students being chosen for the team)
message_2:
To find the number of different teams that can be formed, we will use the binomial coefficient formula, also known as "n choose k". In this case, n = 5 (total number of students) and k = 3 (number of students being chosen for the team).

The formula for "n choose k" is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where "!" denotes the factorial of a number (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

So, for our problem:

C(5, 3) = 5! / (3!(5-3)!)

C(5, 3) = 5! / (3!2!)

C(5, 3) = (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(2 × 1))

C(5, 3) = (120) / (6 × 2)

C(5, 3) = 120 / 12

C(5, 3) = 10

Therefore, 10 different teams can be formed from a group of 5 students.
